awd_titl_txt: Ultrashort Single Photon Generation via Conditional Excitation of an Atomic Barium Ensemble
awd_abstract_narration:
This project explores the use of an atomic barium ensemble as a scalable source of pure ultrashort single photons and the creation, preservation and detection of various types of entanglement between distant photons, atomic ensembles and combinations of both. By applying an off-resonant ultrashort laser pulse to warm atomic barium vapor, we generate a collective excitation in the atomic ensemble, called a spin wave, together with a quantum of electromagnetic excitation, i.e. a photon.  The detection of the photon signals a successful event and the presence of the spin wave in the matter. This long-lived collective excitation can be converted into an ultrashort single photon in a pure wave-packet at a later desired time by applying another ultrashort pulse. By combining numerous atomic ensembles, we are able to create multiple pure ultrashort and identical photons synchronously, an essential requirement for high bit-rate quantum computation and communication applications. The broad bandwidth of the involved fields permits us to study the spectral properties of nonclassical correlations between the created photon and the atomic excitation, adding to our understanding and ability to control the properties of light-matter interaction at the quantum level.

The work of this project provides and demonstrates a method to generate photons suitable for high-speed quantum communication and computation operations, such as entanglement swapping and Bell state measurements. These applications are essential components of protocols such as quantum teleportation, quantum cryptography and Bell inequality detection. Through this project graduate and undergraduate students are trained in experimental and theoretical ultrafast quantum optics and atomic physics. The project serves as the basis for an undergraduate tutorial at the University of Delaware to motivate and improve student understanding of quantum mechanics.

por.por_cntn:
The ability to create and tailor photonic quantum states is important for testing and exploring the fundamentals of quantum mechanics and for future technologies that use quantum phenomena to perform tasks not possible with classical mechanics, such as secure quantum communication, quantum computation and quantum information processing. However, the ability to produce photons that simultaneously match all of the requirements for such applications remains a challenge, despite significant progress in the field. Through this grant we developed and demonstrated new methods to measure, generate, store, and utilize photonic quantum states.

In order to produce photons with the right properties for quantum applications, we must be able to accurately measure those properties. Through this grant we demonstrated the ability of a newly suggested stimulated-emission-based technique to characterize photon-pair joint properties efficiently and with high resolution. Such efficient characterization is a valuable resource for engineering sources of photonic quantum states.

In materials commonly used for photon-pair generation, correlations in frequency between the two photons in the pair exist due to the sudden onset and ending of the light-matter interaction at the front and end face of the material. Through this grant we developed theoretically a method based on the use of two pulses of light with different colors instead of the typical single pulse for controlling the quantum state of photon pairs generated in optical fibers, demonstrating the ability to produce uncorrelated photon-pair states.

Entangled photon pairs are a special quantum state important for many quantum applications. Through this grant we demonstrated a source of ultrashort polarization-entangled photon pairs using off-the-shelf optical fiber as the medium. We also showed that the stimulated-emission-based characterization technique can be used to measure the correlations between the photons in more than one degree of freedom, providing an efficient means to measure and engineer the photon-pair properties. Once created, such photons often need to be stored for use at a later time. Through this grant we demonstrated that warm atomic barium vapor is capable of storing such ultrashort photons.

Light at the single-photon level can also be used to investigate how molecular vibrations change over time. Through this grant we showed that single-photon-level emission produced by exciting molecular liquids with two ultrashort laser pulses can provide information about how the excited molecules lose synchronization.

This grant supported the training of graduate students in experimental and theoretical quantum optics and atomic, molecular and optical physics, and their introduction into the research community through presentations at conferences and writing of manuscripts for publication. Undergraduate students were given an overview of quantum information research through classes at the University of Delaware and through research experience building components for the experiments.
